elements.content: The synthesis is reported of the crown ether substituted tin-containing ferrocenophanes fc(SiMe2CH2)2Sn(X)CH2CH(CH2OC2H4OCH2)2 (1, X = Ph; 2, X = I; 3, X = Cl; 4, X = F) and of the ditopic complex 3·LiCl. The compounds were characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, and cyclic voltammetry. DFT calculations revealed important two-electron stabilization in 3 and 4 due to intramolecular O→Sn coordination that is absent in 2.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis is reported of the crown ether substituted tin-containing ferrocenophanes fc(SiMe2CH2)2Sn(X)CH2CH(CH2OC2H4OCH2)2 (1, X = Ph; 2, X = I; 3, X = Cl; 4, X = F) and of the ditopic complex 3⋅LiCl. The compounds were characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, and cyclic voltammetry. DFT calculations revealed important two-electron stabilization in 3 and 4 due to intramolecular O→Sn coordination that is absent in 2.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of ion pair receptors for selective recognition of anions and cations constitute an emerging field of research. Such receptors have been reported to be able to diminish the effect of counterions observed for monotopic or single ion receptors. Heteroditopic receptors have applications in various fields, such as salt extraction, solubilization, membrane transport, ion sensing applications, and logic gates. A search of the literature showed that many efforts have recently been devoted to the molecular recognition of lithium salts. The growing interest in lithium salts is stimulated by their potential applications in high technology, biological systems, and medicine. Furthermore, lithium complexes of crown ethers have been reported as anionic conductors in manufacturing lithium-based rechargeable batteries and electrolytes and as anion activators in organic synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of ion pair receptors for selective recognition of anions and cations constitute an emerging field of research. Such receptors have been reported to be able to diminish the effect of counterions observed for monotopic or single ion receptors. Heteroditopic receptors have applications in various fields, such as salt extraction, solubilization, membrane transport, ion sensing applications, and logic gates. A search of the literature showed that many efforts have recently been devoted to the molecular recognition of lithium salts. The growing interest in lithium salts is stimulated by their potential applications in high technology, biological systems, and medicine. Furthermore, lithium complexes of crown ethers have been reported as anionic conductors in manufacturing lithium-based rechargeable batteries and electrolytes and as anion activators in organic synthesis.

elements.content: Recently, we reported the organotin- and bis(organostannyl)methane-substituted crown-4, crown-5, and crown-6 compounds of types A– C (Chart ) and demonstrated by means of multinuclear NMR spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction analysis their ability to ditopically complex lithium, sodium, and potassium halides and to transport them through an organic membrane.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we reported the organotin- and bis(organostannyl)methane-substituted crown-4, crown-5, and crown-6 compounds of types A- C (Chart ) and demonstrated by means of multinuclear NMR spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction analysis their ability to ditopically complex lithium, sodium, and potassium halides and to transport them through an organic membrane.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="chart" id="cht1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="om-2013-00219r_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

In a continuation of this work, we have synthesized and structurally characterized the organotin-containing crown ether substituted ferrocenophanes of type D (Chart ). Herein we show that the chloridotriorganotin-substituted [13]-crown-4 ether (type D) can bind LiCl in solution and in the solid state. Its ability to sense LiCl electrochemically has also been investigated. Moreover, theoretical calculations have been performed on compounds of type D. The latter are the first examples of ditopic receptors using an electrochemical reporter group coupled to Lewis acidic organometallic moieties for sensing of ion pairs.

Its ability to sense LiCl electrochemically has also been investigated. Moreover, theoretical calculations have been performed on compounds of type D. The latter are the first examples of ditopic receptors using an electrochemical reporter group coupled to Lewis acidic organometallic moieties for sensing of ion pairs.

elements.content: The reaction of diiodido(1,4,7,10-tetraoxacyclotridec-12-ylmethyl)phenylstannane with fc(Si(Me2)CH2MgCl)2 in THF afforded, after purification by column chromatography, the analytically pure ferrocenophane derivative 1 as a red oil (eq ). Hereafter, fc refers to the 1,1′-disubstituted ferrocene unit.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic Aspects

The reaction of diiodido(1,4,7,10-tetraoxacyclotridec-12-ylmethyl)phenylstannane with fc(Si(Me2)CH2MgCl)2  in THF afforded, after purification by column chromatography, the analytically pure ferrocenophane derivative 1 as a red oil (eq ). Hereafter, fc refers to the 1,1'-disubstituted ferrocene unit. 1

elements.content: Treatment of the tetraorganostannane 1 with 1 mol equiv of elemental iodine provided the triorganotin iodide 2. The latter was reacted with an excess of silver chloride (AgCl) in acetonitrile in the dark to afford the organotin chloride derivative 3. The corresponding organotin fluoride 4 was obtained by the reaction of compound 2 with an excess of potassium fluoride (KF) in the biphasic mixture CH2Cl2/H2O for 4 days (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text: Treatment of the tetraorganostannane 1 with 1 mol equiv of elemental iodine provided the triorganotin iodide 2. The latter was reacted with an excess of silver chloride (AgCl) in acetonitrile in the dark to afford the organotin chloride derivative 3. The corresponding organotin fluoride 4 was obtained by the reaction of compound 2 with an excess of potassium fluoride (KF) in the biphasic mixture CH2Cl2/H2O for 4 days (Scheme ).

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of Compounds 2-4

elements.content:
Compounds 2–4 are orange crystalline materials that are soluble in organic solvents such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, and CH3CN and that are stable under noninert conditions.

Molecular Structures

Single crystals of 2 and 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were grown from their corresponding ethanol solutions at −5 °C, respectively, whereas those of 4 were obtained by slow evaporation from its toluene solution. Compound 2 crystallized in the triclinic space group P1̅ with two molecules per unit cell, while compound 3 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c containing two crystallographically independent molecules A and B per asymmetric unit. Compound 4 crystallized in the orthorhombic space group P212121 containing four molecules in the unit cell.

Molecular Structures

Single crystals of 2 and 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were grown from their corresponding ethanol solutions at -5 °C, respectively, whereas those of 4 were obtained by slow evaporation from its toluene solution. Compound 2 crystallized in the triclinic space group P1̅ with two molecules per unit cell, while compound 3 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c containing two crystallographically independent molecules A and B per asymmetric unit. elements.content:
The molecular structures of compounds 2–4 are shown in Figures – . Selected bond distances and bond angles are collected in Tables and .

The tin atom in compound 2 is four-coordinated and shows a distorted-tetrahedral environment, with angles varying between 119.56(17)° (C(1)–Sn(1)–C(11)) and 100.46(11)° (C(1)–Sn(1)–I(1)). The distortion from the ideal geometry is mainly the result of the O(4) atom approaching the Sn(1) atom via the tetrahedral face defined by C(1), C(11), and I(1) at a distance of 3.670(3) Å. This distance is 0.0200 Å shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of tin (2.17 Å) and oxygen (1.52 Å). Most remarkably, the distance is significantly longer than the corresponding distances found in the tetraorganotin compounds Ph3Sn-CH2-[13]-crown-4 (2.976(16) Å), Ph3Sn-CH2-[16]-crown-5 (3.206(1) Å), Ph3Sn-CH2-[19]-crown-6 (2.9820(13) and 2.9963(14) Å), and {(Ph3SnCH2)2}-[26]-crown-8 (3.1668(23) Å), in the triorganotin iodide Ph2ISnCHCHC(OH)(Me)-t-Bu (2.498(4), 2.550(4) Å,) and in the corresponding monoiodidotriorganotin-substituted crown ethers [Ph2ISn-CH2-[13]-crown-4 (2.466(2) Å) Ph2ISn-CH2-[16]-crown-5 (2.554(2) Å), Ph2ISn-CH2-[19]-crown-6 (2.610(2) Å), and {(PhISnCH2)2}-[26]-crown-8 (2.7985(19) Å). Indeed, the tin atoms in the last group of compounds are, in addition to the coordination to one iodine and three carbon atoms, intramolecularly coordinated to the oxygen atom of the crown ether ring. Compound 2 can be interpreted as a frustrated Lewis pair in which the Lewis base O(4) does not coordinate to the Lewis acidic Sn(1) atom. The origin for this somewhat unexpected behavior might be that the energy gained by the O→Sn coordination is not sufficient to overcome the ring strain that is associated with such coordination to a tin atom that itself is part of the ferrocenophane ring.

The tin atoms in compounds 3 and 4 are pentacoordinated and each exhibit a distorted-trigonal-bipyramidal configuration (geometrical goodness ΔΣ(θ) = 47.6 and 49.5° (3), 52.26° (4)) with C(1), C(11), and C(12) (3, molecule A; 4) and C(31), C(41), and C(42) (3, molecule B) occupying the equatorial and O(1) and Cl(1) (3, molecule A), O(11) and Cl(2) (3, molecule B), and O(1) and F(1) (4) occupying the axial positions. The distortion is best reflected in the O(1)–Sn(1)–Cl(1), O(11)–Sn(2)–Cl(2) (3), and O(1)–Sn(1)–F(1) (4) trans angles of 164.2(5)° (3, molecule A), 161.43(6)° (3, molecule B), and 169.97(11)° (4), which deviate by 15.8, 18.57, and 10.03°, respectively, from the ideal angle of 180°. The tin atoms are displaced by 0.3993(3) Å (3, molecule A), 0.3867(3) Å (3, molecule B), and 0.3632(3) Å (4) from the trigonal planes defined by C(1), C(11), C(12) (molecule A)/C(31), C(41), C(42) (molecule B) in the direction of Cl(1) (3, molecule A)/Cl(2) (3, molecule B) and F(1) (4).

The distortion is best reflected in the O(1)-Sn(1)-Cl(1), O(11)-Sn(2)-Cl(2) (3), and O(1)-Sn(1)-F(1) (4) trans angles of 164.2(5)° (3, molecule A), 161.43(6)° (3, molecule B), and 169.97(11)° (4), which deviate by 15.8, 18.57, and 10.03°, respectively, from the ideal angle of 180°. The tin atoms are displaced by 0.3993(3) Å (3, molecule A), 0.3867(3) Å (3, molecule B), and 0.3632(3) Å (4) from the trigonal planes defined by C(1), C(11), C(12) (molecule A)/C(31), C(41), C(42) (molecule B) in the direction of Cl(1) (3, molecule A)/Cl(2) (3, molecule B) and F(1) (4).

elements.content: In contrast to the triorganotin iodide 2, the triorganotin chloride 3 and triorganotin fluoride 4 exhibit intramolecular O→Sn interactions at distances of 2.629(2) Å (Sn(1)–O(1); 3, molecule A), 2.739(2) Å (Sn(1)–O(1); 3, molecule B), and 2.624(3) Å (Sn(1)–O(1); 4). These distances are longer than those found in other triorganotin halides having intramolecular O→Sn interactions such as 2,6-(MeOCH2)2C6H3SnPh2Cl (Sn–O(1) = 2.567(2) Å), Ph2ClSnCH2-[16]-crown-5 (Sn–O(1) = 2.571(1) Å), (o-MeOC6H4)CH2SnPh2Cl (Sn–O(1) = 2.3991(10) Å), and Ph2FSn-CH2-[16]-crown-5 (2.5301(18) Å). The last two distances 2.739(2) Å (Sn(1)–O(1); 3, molecule B) and 2.624(3) Å (Sn(1)–O(1); 4) are the longest in comparison with the intramolecularly coordinated chloridotriorganotin- and fluoridotriorganotin-substituted crown ethers Ph2ClSn-CH2-[16]-crown-5 (2.571(1) Å), Ph2ClSn-CH2-[19]-crown-6 (2.606(2) Å), and Ph2FSn-CH2-[16]-crown-5 (2.5301(18) Å). As expected, the Sn(1)–Cl(1) and Sn(2)–Cl(2) distances of 2.4394(10) and 2.4383(11) Å in compound 3 and the Sn(1)–F(1) distance of 2.031(2) Å in compound 4 are longer than the corresponding distances in tetracoordinated triorganotin chlorides such as [PhC(CH3)2CH2]3SnCl (Sn(1)–Cl(1) = 2.395(4) Å) and triorganotin fluorides such as Mes3SnF (Sn(1)–F(1) = 1.961(4) Å) and (PhMe2Si)3CSnMe2F (Sn(1)–F(1) = 1.965(2) Å). They exceed the sum of the covalent radii of tin and chlorine by 0.049 and 0.048 Å, respectively, but are close to that of tin and fluorine (2.04 Å), respectively.

elements.content: The 119Sn NMR spectra of compounds 1 and 2 in CDCl3 at room temperature show resonances at δ −25 and 30, respectively, which are close to the 119Sn chemical shifts reported for the tetracoordinated tetraorganotin compounds Me3SnPh (δ −28.6), Me3SnCH2C(CH3)3 (δ −14.4), and Et3SnPh (δ −25.4) and the trioganotin iodide Me3SnI (δ 38.6), respectively. This is evidence that the tin atoms in compounds 1 and 2 are four-coordinated, as observed in the solid state for 2. However, the tin atoms in the triorganotin chloride (3) and fluoride (4) are pentacoordinated, as is evidenced by the 119Sn chemical shifts in CDCl3 of δ 84 (3) and 64 (1 J(119Sn–19F) = 2210 Hz; 4), respectively, being shifted to low frequency as compared with those having comparable substituent patterns at the tin atoms but lacking any chelation, such as Et3SnCl (δ 155) and (PhCMe2CH2)3SnF (δ 139). This observation suggests that the intramolecular O→Sn interaction found in the solid state for 3 and 4 is retained in solution. The 1H NMR show AB-type resonances for the SiCH 2Sn protons at δ 0.28 (1) and δ 0.41 (4) and two resonances for the CH 3 protons at δ 0.12 and 0.20 (1) and δ 0.20 and 0.34 (4).

Structures in Solution

The 119Sn NMR spectra of compounds 1 and 2 in CDCl3 at room temperature show resonances at δ -25 and 30, respectively, which are close to the 119Sn chemical shifts reported for the tetracoordinated tetraorganotin compounds Me3SnPh (δ -28.6), Me3SnCH2C(CH3)3 (δ -14.4), and Et3SnPh (δ -25.4) and the trioganotin iodide Me3SnI (δ 38.6), respectively. This is evidence that the tin atoms in compounds 1 and 2 are four-coordinated, as observed in the solid state for 2. However, the tin atoms in the triorganotin chloride (3) and fluoride (4) are pentacoordinated, as is evidenced by the 119Sn chemical shifts in CDCl3 of δ 84 (3) and 64 (1 J(119Sn-19F) = 2210 Hz; 4), respectively, being shifted to low frequency as compared with those having comparable substituent patterns at the tin atoms but lacking any chelation, such as Et3SnCl (δ 155) and (PhCMe2CH2)3SnF (δ 139). This observation suggests that the intramolecular O→Sn interaction found in the solid state for 3 and 4 is retained in solution. The 1H NMR show AB-type resonances for the SiCH 2Sn protons at δ 0.28 (1) and δ 0.41 (4) and two resonances for the CH 3 protons at δ 0.12 and 0.20 (1) and δ 0.20 and 0.34 (4).

elements.content: The ESI-MS spectra in the positive mode of compounds 2–4 are characterized by the observation of a mass cluster centered at m/z 651.1 that is assigned to {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnCH2-[13]-crown-4]}+. In addition, for 2 there are less intense mass clusters centered at m/z 668.1 and 691.1 that are assigned to {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnCH2-[13]-crown-4·OH]}+ and {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnCH2-[13]-crown-4]·OH·Na}+, respectively. Furthermore, a mass cluster centered at m/z 670.1 is observed in the ESI-MS spectrum in the positive mode of compound 4 that is assigned to {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnFCH2-[13]-crown-4]}+. No tin-containing mass cluster is observed in the ESI-MS spectrum in the negative mode of compound 2, whereas an intense mass cluster centered at m/z 721.0 is observed in the ESI-MS spectrum (negative mode) of compound 3 that is assigned to {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnClCH2-[13]-crown-4·Cl]}−.

elements.content: The ability of compounds 3 and 4 to complex salts was studied. Thus, the 119Sn NMR spectrum of compound 4 in CD3CN to which had been added 1 molar equiv of tetraethylammonium fluoride, (Et4NF·2H2O) showed no resonance at room temperature, whereas at T = −84 °C, a low-frequency-shifted triplet resonance at δ −121 (1 J(119Sn–19F) = 1737 Hz) was observed (, Figure S2). The 19F NMR spectrum at room temperature displayed a broad resonance at δ −116 (ν1/2 = 1612 Hz) (, Figure S3). At T = −84 °C, the signal sharpened (δ −113.6, ν1/2 = 99 Hz) and showed unresolved 1 J(19F–117/119Sn) satellites of 1748 Hz (, Figure S4). These data indicate Sn–F exchange processes (Scheme ) being fast at room temperature and slow at low temperature on the corresponding NMR time scales.
elements.clean_text:
Complexation Studies

The ability of compounds 3 and 4 to complex salts was studied. Thus, the 119Sn NMR spectrum of compound 4 in CD3CN to which had been added 1 molar equiv of tetraethylammonium fluoride, (Et4NF⋅2H2O) showed no resonance at room temperature, whereas at T = -84 °C, a low-frequency-shifted triplet resonance at δ -121 (1 J(119Sn-19F) = 1737 Hz) was observed (, Figure S2). The 19F NMR spectrum at room temperature displayed a broad resonance at δ -116 (ν1/2 = 1612 Hz) (, Figure S3). At T = -84 °C, the signal sharpened (δ -113.6, ν1/2 = 99 Hz) and showed unresolved 1 J(19F-117/119Sn) satellites of 1748 Hz (, Figure S4). These data indicate Sn-F exchange processes (Scheme ) being fast at room temperature and slow at low temperature on the corresponding NMR time scales.

In the negative mode, there are mass clusters centered at m/z 689.1 and 729.1 that are assigned to {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnFCH2-[13]-crown-4·F]}− and {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnFCH2-[13]-crown-4·F·OH·Na]}−, respectively. A less intense mass cluster was observed at m/z 1356.6, which corresponds to the species {[fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2Sn(μ-F)CH2-[13]-crown-4]2·H2O]}−.

elements.content: The 119Sn NMR as well as the 19F NMR spectra at 22 °C of a solution of 4 in CD3CN to which had been added 1 molar equiv of lithium fluoride (LiF) showed no change. This finding is fully in line with the result obtained for the reaction between the triorganotin fluoride PhFSn-CH2-[13]-crown-4 and LiF and reveals that compound 4 is not able to overcome the high lattice energy (1033 kJ/mol) of LiF and to ditopically complex the latter. The 119Sn and 19F NMR spectra did not change after the same sample had been stored for 3 weeks, indicating that the nonformation of a ditopic complex is not the result of kinetics.

elements.content: The 119Sn NMR spectrum of compound 3 in CDCl3 at room temperature to which had been added an excess of lithium chloride (LiCl) showed a single resonance at δ 84, indicating no formation of the corresponding chloride complex. However, the 119Sn NMR resonance shifted from δ 67 to −28 (, Figures S5 and S6) when the reaction was carried out in CD3CN, indicating formation of the 1:1 ditopic complex [3·LiCl] shown in Scheme .

elements.content: Further experimental support for the formation of [3·LiCl] stems from the 1H, 7Li, and 13C NMR spectra and ESI-MS spectrometry. The 1H NMR spectrum of [3·LiCl] in CD3CN showed that the signals of the methine (HC12) and SiCH 2Sn protons are shifted to high frequency by 0.24 and 0.1 ppm, respectively, whereas that of the HC14 hydrogen atoms is shifted by 0.06 ppm to low frequency (for numbering scheme see Chart ). The 7Li NMR spectrum shows a sharp singlet resonance at δ −1.1, indicating that LiCl is indeed dissolved as result of complexation by the crown ether. Appreciable changes in the 13C NMR spectrum of 3 in CD3CN were seen upon treatment with excess LiCl. The resonances of the C11/C13, C14, and SiCH2Sn carbon atoms are displaced to high frequency by 5.46, 2.64, and 5.24 ppm, respectively, while those of the C12 and C2–C9 crown ether carbon atoms are moved by 0.59 and 1.57 ppm to low frequencies, respectively. The ESI-MS spectrum in the positive mode of [3·LiCl] showed an intense mass cluster centered at m/z 693.1 that was assigned to {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnClCH2-[13]-crown-4·Li]}+. A less intense mass cluster was observed at m/z 1395.3 that was assigned to {[fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2Sn(μ–Cl)CH2-[13]-crown-4]2·Na]}+. In the ESI-MS spectrum (negative mode) of [3·LiCl], there was an intense mass cluster centered at m/z 721.1 that was assigned to {fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnClCH2-[13]-crown-4·Cl]}−.

elements.content: The formation of the ditopic complex [3·LiCl] was confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by slow evaporation of a solution of [3·LiCl] at room temperature in acetonitrile. [3·LiCl] crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21 with two molecules per unit cell. The molecular structure of [3·LiCl] is shown in Figure . Selected bond distances and bond angles are collected in Table .

Symmetry codes: (a) −x, −0.5 + y, 1 – z; (b) −x, 0.5 + y, 1 – z.

The molecular structure of [3·LiCl] shows that the LiCl salt is complexed as a host-separated ion pair with the lithium cation being bound inside the cavity of the crown ether and the chloride anion being bound to the tin atom. There is an intermolecular Cl(2b)···Li(1) interaction at a distance of 2.329(8) Å that is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Li (1.81 Å) and Cl (1.75 Å) and even shorter than the Li···Cl distance in crystalline lithium chloride (2.565 Å), which gives rise to the formation of a one-dimensional polymeric chain structure (Figure ). Such a binding mode was also reported by Reetz and co-workers for the complexation of potassium fluoride (KF) by a crown ether moiety coupled to a Lewis acidic boron center. Remarkably, and in contrast to the common crystal structures of lithium salts complexed by macrocycles, there is no incorporation of water within the coordination sphere of Li+. The lithium cation is five-coordinated and adopts a distorted-square-pyramidal environment, with the four crown ether oxygen atoms forming the base of the pyramid and the chloride anion of the neighbor molecule occupying the apical position. The lithium cation lies 0.756(8) Å above the pyramid plane in the direction of Cl(2B). The average Li–Ocrown distance of 2.019 Å is close to the average standard Li–O distance (2.032 Å) found for the Li+ ionophores having the coordination number 5 and a square-pyramidal coordination geometry.

elements.content: The tin atom is pentacoordinated and exhibits a distorted -trigonal-bipyramidal environment (geometrical goodness ΔΣ(θ) = 80.31°) with the C(1), C(11), and C(12) carbon atoms occupying the equatorial and Cl(1) and Cl(2) occupying the axial positions. The Sn(1) atom is displaced by 0.1156(2) Å from the trigonal plane in the direction of Cl(1). As a result of the intermolecular Li(1)···Cl(2b) interaction, the Sn(1)–Cl(2) distance of 2.7706(11) Å is longer than the Sn(1)–Cl(1) distance of 2.5287(11) Å. Both distances exceed the sum of the covalent radii of Sn (1.40 Å) and Cl (0.99 Å). They are longer than those found in the parent compound 3 and the corresponding distances in the dichloridodiorganotin-substituted crown ether PhCl2Sn-CH2-[13]-crown-4 (2.4190(5) Å).

The Sn(1) atom is displaced by 0.1156(2) Å from the trigonal plane in the direction of Cl(1). As a result of the intermolecular Li(1)⋅⋅⋅Cl(2b) interaction, the Sn(1)-Cl(2) distance of 2.7706(11) Å is longer than the Sn(1)-Cl(1) distance of 2.5287(11) Å. elements.content: Upon oxidation in CH3CN/0.1 M Bu4NPF6 at a glassy-carbon (GC) microdisk electrode, the compounds 3, 4, and [3·LiCl] (Figure ) show well-shaped reversible one-electron peaks (E1) of the formation of the corresponding ferrocenium cations. Similar results were observed when using Bu4NClO4 as supporting salt: the E° values remained practically unchanged, within ±5 mV. The E° values of all three compounds are more positive than the E° value of nonsubstituted ferrocene and are close to those reported for other silyl-substituted ferrocenophanes, 1,1′-bis[dimethyl(vinyl)silyl]ferrocenes, and 1,1′-bis-silylferrocenylenes, in accordance with the electron-acceptor effects of tetracoordinated silyl substituents. A similar trend was earlier reported for the E 1/2 of ferrocene derivatives substituted with Si(OMe)3 or SiH3 in the 1,1′-positions. The first oxidation step is followed by a second oxidation (E 2) at E p ≅ 1.75 V arising from the oxidation of the crown ether moiety; the feature is common to all three compounds. In the cathodic scan, no reductions are observed up to ≅–2.7 V; at lower negative potentials reductive cleavage of the Sn–Cl bond occurs (E3), which led to the appearance and growth of the oxidation peak of free Cl– anion (E4) on the anodic branch in the second and following scans. The peak at E4 is not present in the original nonreduced system, implying that the hypercoordinate organotin chloride complex [3·LiCl] exists in solution in a nondissociated form (Figure ).

elements.content: The E° value of [3·LiCl] is shifted by an overall 58 mV to more positive potentials in comparison to E° of ferrocene, primarily due to the electron-withdrawing effects of two substituents on the cyclopentadienyl rings. In this difference two opposite shifts are also observed: to less anodic potentials due to the coordination with Cl– and to more positive potentials due to the complexation of Li+.

elements.content: The addition of 2 equiv of LiCl to a solution of 3 (the same effect was observed upon stepwise addition, first of LiClO4 and then of HexMe2(C16H33)NCl) caused a −66 mV cathodic shift of E°(3), which now became exactly that of the ditopic complex [3·LiCl]; E°(3 + LiCl) = 0.155 V (Table ). The same effect was observed upon stepwise addition of the corresponding ions: first of LiClO4 (shift by Li+: ΔE° = +8 mV) and then of HexMe2(C16H33)NCl) (shift by Cl–: ΔE° = −74 mV). Ensuing addition of the F– anion (as Bu4NF, 5 equiv) to this solution caused two phenomena: (i) the temporary appearance of a small signal of the new ferrocene-related redox system (prepeak) at remarkably negative potentials (E° = −0.172 V, Figure ) and (ii) the shift of the E° value of [3·LiCl] by 30 mV to more positive potentials, reaching E°([3·LiCl]) = 0.185 V. Within several minutes, the system at −0.172 V progressively disappeared and the standard potential of the main redox couple shifted back, becoming constant at E°([3·LiCl]) = 0.165 V. These features probably reflect an additional coordination of F– to the tin atom, the prepeak being that of oxidation of the species with hexacoordinated tin.

elements.content: The fluorido-substituted derivative 4 has a lower oxidation potential in comparison to the chlorido-substituted derivative 3 (Table ), which implies that the electronegativity of the halogen atom is not the major factor determining the electronic effects exerted by the substituent on the Fc moiety. The inversed order of E° for 3 and 4 might arise from an additional back-bonding from the halogen lone pair to vacant orbitals of Sn, similarly to what was observed earlier for Sn–X electronic interactions in tricarbastannatranes. The addition of lithium perchlorate, LiClO4, to a solution of 4 caused the expected further increase in E°, which now became E° = 0.155 V (Figure ). The effect of Li+ on E°(4) is stronger (ΔE° = +34 mV) than that on E°(3) and is additive whatever the order of its addition is (before or after Cl– or F– and whatever the order of addition of the anions). In contrast, the order of addition of anions and also whether Li+ is present or not both affect the ΔE°(4) caused by Cl– and F–, so that no simple trend could be established. For instance, the addition of fluoride anion (as Bu4NF) to the solution 4 + Li+ led to another increase of the oxidation potential, E° = 0.191 V, whereas the addition of Cl– caused a shift of −68 mV. This is quite unexpected, because coordination with anions is thought to provide supplementary electron density to Sn and hence to decrease E°. It is also to be noted that, in the presence of F–, a new oxidation peak with E p = 0.6 V is appeared (Figure ).

elements.content: The usual optimization approach (low-level followed by high-level calculations) proved unsuitable for 2–4. In fact, although the 3-21G basis set includes the functions for Sn, enabling primary optimization of these compounds, it did not allow localizing O→Sn coordinated structures as minima: even starting from forcefully coordinated geometries, noncoordinated structures were obtained at HF/3-21G and DFT/3-21G levels. Only the optimization with a combined basis set treating at the ECP LANL2DZ level all elements but Fe and Sn (for which split valence double-ζ DGDZVP or Ahlrichs’ Def2-TZVP triple-ζ valence balanced basis sets are required) provided experiment-consistent structures. The NBO and CHelpG population analyses were then performed at the same level of theory on the optimized non-zero-frequency structures.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

The usual optimization approach (low-level followed by high-level calculations) proved unsuitable for 2-4. In fact, although the 3-21G basis set includes the functions for Sn, enabling primary optimization of these compounds, it did not allow localizing O→Sn coordinated structures as minima: even starting from forcefully coordinated geometries, noncoordinated structures were obtained at HF/3-21G and DFT/3-21G levels. Only the optimization with a combined basis set treating at the ECP LANL2DZ level all elements but Fe and Sn (for which split valence double-ζ DGDZVP or Ahlrichs' Def2-TZVP triple-ζ valence balanced basis sets are required) provided experiment-consistent structures. The NBO and CHelpG population analyses were then performed at the same level of theory on the optimized non-zero-frequency structures.

elements.content: The DFT trend in the O→Sn coordination is in line with the X-ray diffraction data. The chlorido- and fluorido-substituted derivatives 3 and 4 are O→Sn coordinated, whereas the corresponding iodido-substituted derivative 2 is not (Figure ). The O–Sn–X angles in 3 (161.00°) and 4 (166.52°) are smaller but still closer to the ideal 180° than that in 2, for which it is closer to a right angle (105.73°). The sum of the three C–Sn–C angles in 3 and 4 is also closer to 360° than in 2 (Table ).

elements.content: From second-order perturbation theory analysis, no direct dative interactions (above the threshold of 0.5 kcal/mol) are seen between Sn and O in compound 2. The energy of σ(Sn–C)−σ*(O–C) orbital interactions and of p z (O) with a vacant hybrid orbital of Sn is only 1.34 kcal/mol, too low to enable any efficient coordination. In 3, there is an important two-electron stabilization due to electron delocalization from p z (O) to the empty hybrid orbital of Sn amounting to 28.91 kcal/mol (27.28 kcal/mol in 4) with an additional 13.56 kcal/mol (12.12 kcal/mol in 4) from the interactions of s and p lone pairs of O with three σ*(Sn–C) orbitals.

elements.content: Thus, both the charge and orbital terms of the energy gain from O→Sn coordination are the lowest for 2 in comparison to 3 and 4. This attractive energy is opposed to the steric strain of the ferrocenophane ring and steric repulsion of the dimethylsilyl and crown ether moieties. In 3 and 4, this ratio is favorable for realizing stable O→Sn coordinated structures, while steric forces prevail for 2. A fine interplay of these factors is also seen through DFT calculations. The simplified optimization procedures (freezing Fc fragment or setting it as an ONIOM lower layer) do not converge to Sn–O coordinated structures, even for 3 and 4, unless the Fe atom is treated at the same level as Sn (DGDZVP or Def2-TZVP). Although the difference is only about the energy of modification of the angle between two Cp rings and of their rotation about their axes relative to the Fe atom, the flip of the Fc moiety about two Sn–C bonds has an activation energy that delimits coordinated and noncoordinated structures. In the solid state, the dihedral angles Si(1)–C(11)–Sn–X and Si(2)–C(12)–Sn–X in 3 and 4 are both greater than 90° and are less than 90° in 2. In DFT optimized structures of 3 and 4 (Figure ) this angle is also >90°, but only a half-flip is observed for 2 (Si(1)–C(11)–Sn–X < 90° and Si(2)–C(12)–Sn–X > 90°).

elements.content: A series of novel silicon- and tin-containing ferrocenophanes was synthesized and completely characterized, and their ability in the ditopic complexation of lithium salts was investigated by NMR spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, and crystallography. In the solid state as well as in solution, the chlorido- and fluorido-substituted derivatives 3 and 4, respectively, show intramolecular O→Sn coordination, whereas the iodido-substituted derivative 2 does not. This somewhat unexpected observation is confirmed by DFT calculations. It is the result of steric hindrance that in the case of 2 dominates the energy gain (smaller than in 3 and 4) from the intramolecular O→Sn coordination. The chlorido-substituted ferrocenophane 3 is able to selectively complex lithium chloride in a ditopic fashion to give [3·LiCl]. However, in the solid state the charge separation induced by this complexation is compensated for by the formation of a coordination polymer via intermolecular Cl···Li interactions. Consequently, in order to achieve true charge separation the lithium cation should be encapsulated in a cryptand or a crown-4 derivative that is more protected by appropriate substituents.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of novel silicon- and tin-containing ferrocenophanes was synthesized and completely characterized, and their ability in the ditopic complexation of lithium salts was investigated by NMR spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, and crystallography. In the solid state as well as in solution, the chlorido- and fluorido-substituted derivatives 3 and 4, respectively, show intramolecular O→Sn coordination, whereas the iodido-substituted derivative 2 does not. This somewhat unexpected observation is confirmed by DFT calculations. It is the result of steric hindrance that in the case of 2 dominates the energy gain (smaller than in 3 and 4) from the intramolecular O→Sn coordination. The chlorido-substituted ferrocenophane 3 is able to selectively complex lithium chloride in a ditopic fashion to give [3⋅LiCl]. However, in the solid state the charge separation induced by this complexation is compensated for by the formation of a coordination polymer via intermolecular Cl⋅⋅⋅Li interactions. Consequently, in order to achieve true charge separation the lithium cation should be encapsulated in a cryptand or a crown-4 derivative that is more protected by appropriate substituents.

elements.content: An interesting formal analogy can be drawn between [3·LiCl] and the zwitterionic 2-(N,N-dimethylammoniomethyl)phenyl-containing triorganodichloridostannate 2-Me2HNCH2C6H4SnCl2Ph2 and related derivatives. In the latter compound, a proton is coordinated by the amine nitrogen atom (Lewis base) and a chloride anion is coordinated to a tin atom (Lewis acid). However, complete charge separation is not achieved, as the chloride anion intramolecularly interacts with the triorganoammonium moiety (N–H···Cl).

In the latter compound, a proton is coordinated by the amine nitrogen atom (Lewis base) and a chloride anion is coordinated to a tin atom (Lewis acid). However, complete charge separation is not achieved, as the chloride anion intramolecularly interacts with the triorganoammonium moiety (N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl).

Experimental Section

General Methods

Solvents were dried and distilled from the appropriate desiccants prior to use. All manipulations were performed under an inert atmosphere of argon. Elemental iodine (I2), AgCl, KF, ET4NF⋅2H2O, LiF and LiCl were commercially available. Literature procedures were used to prepare 1,1'-bis[(chloromethyl)dimethylsilyl]ferrocene and diiodo(1,4,7,10-tetraoxacyclotridec-12-ylmethyl)diphenylstannane. The atom numbering of the crown ether moieties is shown in Chart .

elements.content: These spectra were recorded on a Thermoquest-Finnigan instrument using CH3CN as the mobile phase. The samples were introduced as solutions in CH3CN via a syringe pump operating at 0.5 μL/min. The capillary voltage was 4.5 kV, while the cone skimmer voltage varied between 50 and 250 kV. Identification of the expected ions was assisted by comparison of experimental and calculated isotope distribution patterns. The m/z values reported correspond to those of the most intense peak in the corresponding isotope pattern.
elements.clean_text:
Electrospray Mass Spectra

These spectra were recorded on a Thermoquest-Finnigan instrument using CH3CN as the mobile phase. The samples were introduced as solutions in CH3CN via a syringe pump operating at 0.5 μL/min. The capillary voltage was 4.5 kV, while the cone skimmer voltage varied between 50 and 250 kV. Identification of the expected ions was assisted by comparison of experimental and calculated isotope distribution patterns. The m/z values reported correspond to those of the most intense peak in the corresponding isotope pattern.

elements.content: Intensity data for the crystals 2–4 and [3·LiCl] were collected on an XcaliburS CCD diffractometer (Oxford Diffraction) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation at 173 K. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97. Refinements were carried out against F 2 by using SHELXL-97. The C–H hydrogen atoms were positioned with idealized geometry and refined using a riding model. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic displacement parameters, except disordered atoms of compound 2 (O(2′), O(3′), C(5), C(5′), C(6), and C(6′)), which remained isotropic to benefit the data/parameter ratio. Part of the crown ether in compound 2 is affected by disorder (atoms O(2), O(3), C(5), and C(6)); the disorder was refined by a split model and occupancy values were allowed to refine freely until a constant number was obtained (0.59537). The crystallographic data are given in the (Table S1). For decimal rounding of numerical parameters and su values the rules of the IUCr have been employed.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Intensity data for the crystals 2-4 and [3⋅LiCl] were collected on an XcaliburS CCD diffractometer (Oxford Diffraction) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation at 173 K. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97. Refinements were carried out against F 2 by using SHELXL-97. The C-H hydrogen atoms were positioned with idealized geometry and refined using a riding model. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic displacement parameters, except disordered atoms of compound 2 (O(2'), O(3'), C(5), C(5'), C(6), and C(6')), which remained isotropic to benefit the data/parameter ratio. Part of the crown ether in compound 2 is affected by disorder (atoms O(2), O(3), C(5), and C(6)); the disorder was refined by a split model and occupancy values were allowed to refine freely until a constant number was obtained (0.59537). The crystallographic data are given in the  (Table S1). For decimal rounding of numerical parameters and su values the rules of the IUCr have been employed.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammetry has been carried out using a PAR 2273A digital potentiostat piloted by PowerSuite software. A standard 5 mL three-electrode electrochemical cell was used with the auxiliary electrode (Pt wire) separated from the analyte by a sintered-glass tube. Bu4NPF6, HexMe2(C16H33)NCl, LiCl, and LiClO4 (Aldrich) were dried under vacuum and kept over P2O5. Bu4NF (Aldrich) was used as a 1 M solution in THF. All experiments were performed in dry CH3CN.
elements.clean_text:
Voltammetry and DFT Calculations

Cyclic voltammetry has been carried out using a PAR 2273A digital potentiostat piloted by PowerSuite software. A standard 5 mL three-electrode electrochemical cell was used with the auxiliary electrode (Pt wire) separated from the analyte by a sintered-glass tube. Bu4NPF6, HexMe2(C16H33)NCl, LiCl, and LiClO4 (Aldrich) were dried under vacuum and kept over P2O5. Bu4NF (Aldrich) was used as a 1 M solution in THF. All experiments were performed in dry CH3CN.

elements.content:
For DFT modeling, the Gaussian-03 package and its facilities for structure optimization, NBO, and CHelpG charge calculations were used.

Synthesis of 1-Phenyl-1-(1,4,7,10-tetraoxacyclotridec-12-ylmethyl)-3,3,14,14-tetramethyl-3,14-disila-1-stanna[5,5]-ferrocenophane (<bold>1</bold>; fc[(Si(Me)<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SnPhCH<sub>2</sub>-[13]-crown-4])

A solution of fc(SiMe2CH2MgCl)2 prepared from fc(SiMe2CH2Cl)2 (0.48 g, 1.23 mmol) and magnesium (0.12 g, 4.9 mmol) in THF (20 mL) was added dropwise to a stirred solution of PhI2SnCH2-[13]-crown-4 (0.80 g, 1.23 mmol) in THF (40 mL). After the addition had been completed, the reaction mixture was heated to reflux overnight and then cooled to room temperature. Cold water (30 mL) was added, and the mixture was extracted two times with 40 mL of dichloromethane. The combined organic phases were dried with MgSO4 and filtered, and the solvents were evaporated in vacuo to give the crude product. The latter was purified by column chromatography (SiO2, isohexane/ethyl acetate (3/1)) to yield 0.36 g (40%) of pure 1 as a red viscous oil.

Over a period of 2 h, iodine (42 mg, 0.17 mmol) was added in small portions at 0 °C to a stirred solution of 1 (0.12 g, 0.17 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL). Stirring was continued and the reaction mixture was warmed to room temperature overnight. Dichloromethane and iodobenzene were removed in vacuo (10–3 mmHg) to afford an orange solid. Recrystallization from ethanol at −5 °C gave 0.12 g (92%) of pure 2 as orange crystals, mp 122.6 °C.

To a solution of 2 (0.52 g, 0.67 mmol) in CH3CN (25 mL) was added excess silver chloride (AgCl; 0.29 g, 2 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature in the dark for 14 days. After the AgI that formed and the nonreacted AgCl were removed by filtration, the solvent was evaporated in vacuo (10–3 mmHg) to afford an orange solid. Recrystallization from ethanol at −5 °C gave 0.4 g (87%) of pure 3 as orange crystals, mp 131.5 °C.

To a solution of 2 (0.52 g, 0.67 mmol) in CH3CN (25 mL) was added excess silver chloride (AgCl; 0.29 g, 2 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature in the dark for 14 days. After the AgI that formed and the nonreacted AgCl were removed by filtration, the solvent was evaporated in vacuo (10-3 mmHg) to afford an orange solid. Recrystallization from ethanol at -5 °C gave 0.4 g (87%) of pure 3 as orange crystals, mp 131.5 °C.

Synthesis of 1-Fluorido-1-(1,4,7,10-tetraoxacyclotridec-12-ylmethyl)-3,3,14,14-tetramethyl-3,14-disila-1-stanna[5,5]-ferrocenophane, (4; fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnFCH2-[13]-crown-4])

A solution of 2 (0.11 g, 0.14 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) was mixed with a solution of KF (0.08 g, 1.42 mmol) in water (15 mL). The biphasic mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 days. The organic phase was then separated, dried over MgSO4, and filtered. Removing the solvent in vacuo afforded an orange viscous oil. The latter was dissolved in toluene. Slow evaporation of this solution afforded 0.06 g (63%) of 4 as orange crystals, mp 127.4 °C.

Synthesis of the Ditopic Complex fc[(Si(Me)2CH2)2SnClCH2-[13]-crown-4⋅LiCl] ([3⋅LiCl])

Lithium chloride (0.02 g, 0.47 mmol) was added to a solution of 3 (0.14 g, 0.20 mmol) in CH3CN (8 mL), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. After filtration of excess salt, slow evaporation of acetonitrile at room temperature provided 0.09 g (61%) of pure [3⋅LiCl] as orange crystals, mp 211.7 °C.
